speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.1: COVID Mask Policy - The board will discuss the district’s COVID-19 health protocols, specifically whether students should be required to wear masks while in classrooms. This policy would apply during the regular school day, with exceptions for lunch and designated mask-break periods. The goal is to balance student safety with comfort and learning effectiveness.. Who would like to start?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thanks, Graham. I know there’s been some concern about how consistent our messaging has been. Maybe it’d help to hear what families are saying—has anyone reached out lately?

speaker: kateacuff
content: David, I agree we need better messaging. I'd like to hear from Dr. Gipson about current case rates and risk assessment. Should we adjust our policy based on those numbers?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Kate, I think Dr. Gipson could definitely weigh in, but maybe we should check—have we updated our data dashboard recently?

speaker: kateacuff
content: That's a good point, David. I'm not sure if we've had an update since last week. Is that something we can get today or next week?

speaker: judyle
content:
Thank you, Kate. I appreciate your question. Could someone confirm when we last refreshed the dashboard? I’m wondering if we’re using real-time data or lagged information.  

Also, does anyone have feedback from parents who’ve expressed discomfort with the new protocol? I want to understand how widespread those concerns are.

And just so we’re clear—I think we should all feel comfortable asking for clarification when needed. Does anyone else have thoughts on the timing of updates?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thanks, Julie. I appreciate your questions.  

I wonder—do we know how many families actually contacted us directly about this?  

Could someone please pull up the latest parent feedback logs?  

Just to clarify, are we still relying on state-level case counts, or did we switch to local testing data?  

If we're using older data, shouldn’t we refresh it before deciding?  

Would anyone mind checking the dashboard now to see if it’s current?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content:
Good morning, everybody. I appreciate everyone’s input. I hope everyone feels safe and healthy. And I really appreciate the way we’re being respectful of each other.

Dr. Gipson, I was wondering, could you give us a quick status report on where things stand right now?

Do you think we should continue with the masking requirement? Or do you think it might be time to reevaluate it?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Thank you, Graham. Hi, everyone. Sorry I was late getting here. So I guess my first question would be, has the guidance changed since we met two weeks ago?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Katrina, I don’t think there’s been a change at the state level, but I think we ought to double-check. Do we know if anything’s shifted since then?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yeah, because I guess I was going to say, I don't remember seeing anything different. So I don't know. I mean, I don't know what the answer is. But I'm assuming it hasn't changed. It seems like we were told that the CDC said that the delta variant wasn't particularly dangerous for kids, which I thought was kind of interesting.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Katrinacallsen, I don't know if that's accurate, but I certainly haven't seen any changes. I do believe that we've been looking at our own data more closely. I wonder if Dr. Gipson might comment on that.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Sure.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Ellen. I appreciate the clarity.  
Can someone verify the timeline for the most recent parent contact log update?  
And Dr. Gipson, could you walk us through what the current local case rate trends show?  
Maybe we could look at hospitalization data too—is that available yet?  
It’s probably worth checking if those metrics are driving any decisions.  
Could someone please send over the latest county-level data for review?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Julie, thanks for the follow-up.
Could someone please confirm when the parent contacts log was last updated?
I’d love to see the actual number of complaints—just to gauge urgency.
Dr. Gipson, can you tell us what percentage of cases are currently among unvaccinated children?
Please check if hospitalizations are rising locally again.
And could we get the full breakdown by grade level, especially K–5?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thank you, Ellen. I appreciate that. I'm sorry I missed part of the exchange earlier.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yeah, no problem.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Jon, I’ll let you speak after I ask—Julie, do we even have a full count of how many families have actually raised concerns?

speaker: kateacuff
content: I don't think we do, David. I wonder if someone on staff might have that. Judi, could you possibly check that?

speaker: judyle
content:
Thank you, Kate. I’d appreciate that. Judi, could you please pull the total count of family concerns reported since Monday?
And while you’re at it, could you flag any recurring themes in those messages?
Also, Dr. Gipson, do we have age-specific positivity rates for elementary students?
Is there any sign that symptoms are worsening in younger children?
Could we get a snapshot of that data within the next ten minutes?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Julie, thanks for pushing on that.
Judi, could you please pull the exact number of distinct concerns logged since Monday?
And if possible, sort them by severity—especially any mentioning health risks?
Dr. Gipson, do we know if breakthrough infections are increasing in vaccinated adults?
Could we get a side-by-side comparison between symptomatic and asymptomatic cases in kids under 10?
Please share that with us ASAP.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thank you, Ellen. And I apologize, but I didn’t catch whether or not we got the numbers. Judi, could you please provide the totals?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I'm sorry, I didn't hear that either.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Judi, could you please read out the raw number of reports you pulled?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Judi, could you please read out the raw number of reports you pulled?

speaker: judyle
content:
Judi, could you please repeat the raw number of reports for the group?
Judie, I think I heard “thirty-six”—is that correct?
And Dr. Gipson, maybe we could compare that to prior weeks—does that trend seem concerning?
Could someone pull the week-over-week comparison real quick?

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote privately.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.1: Should the district require students to wear masks in classrooms during the school day?.  If each of you could please record your vote in the chat, I will tally them up and announce the results.

speaker: davidoberg
content: yes

speaker: kateacuff
content: I reviewed the conversation about mask requirements. I am concerned about the potential impact on student learning from extended absences due to exposure and quarantines. While I recognize the importance of safety, I also want to ensure we're minimizing disruptions to education. Given this balance, I will vote "no" on requiring masks in classrooms.

speaker: judyle
content: yes

speaker: ellenosborne
content: yes

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content:
The most important thing about this question is that parents and guardians are going to be making decisions based upon what they're hearing from their children and what they see when they come home.
I would hope that every parent has some common sense when they look at these things. That said, my son went back to school yesterday, and he was wearing a mask. He doesn't like wearing a mask. But I told him, "Son, go ahead and put it on." Because I want him to stay healthy. I want him to stay safe. So I voted yes.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: abstain

speaker: grahampaige
content: All right, Ms. Lee, could you call the roll on this item?
